results.title: Fate of a child
results.creator_credit: United Nations. Film Board and Leo Seltzer
results.brief_description: The death of a child is dramatised to show the living conditions in an under-developed area in Latin America. People surrounded by potential wealth live in poverty, starvation and ignorance. Technical assistance by the United Nations will help to eliminate the conditions responsible for the death of this child, through the economic development of such areas.

results.title: Fatal compromise
results.creator_credit: MAFILM Pannonia Filmstudio and Josef Gemes
results.brief_description: A superbly animated production that details the lengths to which a love-smitten hedgehog will go in order to gain the attention of a rather large feline character. However the hedgehog does not quite get what it bargained for. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Fat of the land
results.creator_credit: Baptist Pork Production in association with Civilian Tragedy
results.brief_description: A compilation of short British ‘art-house’ films 1984-1987 as follows: “Procar” (dirs. Richard Heslop, Daniel Landin), A Nosegay” (dir. Maggie Jailler), “Thou pluckest me out screaming (dir. Daniel Landin), “Epiphany (excerpt)” (dir. Certh Wyn Evens), “The Sluggard” (dir. Joy Perino), “Language” (dir. Richard Heslop), “Less then useless” (dirs. Richard Heslop, Carrie Kirkpatrick) and “The Conversation” (dirs. Timothy Burke, Richard Heslop)

results.title: Fat of the land
results.creator_credit: Searle Educational Systems, Medcom and Edmond Levy
results.brief_description: Documentary on obesity, its causes and effects. Psychiatrists suggest that over-eating is a form of emotional disorder leading to addiction and that in the United States in particular, food has become symbolic as a state of well-being. It appears that children are actually encouraged to over-eat leading to difficulties in adult life to break the habit. The program’s main aim is to educate in the area of health and nutrition.

results.title: Fat freedom
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Derek Lamb and Richard Capaner
results.brief_description: Using soft washes of colour, this animated film portrays a man’s desire to escape his heavy human body, changing it into forms that let him fly, dance and rejoice and allow him to express his inner needs and fantasies. Music by Ben Low.

results.title: Fat and proud of it
results.creator_credit: CBS News and Wombat Productions, Inc.
results.brief_description: At a meeting of the National Association to Aid Fat Americans people discuss fat pride, fat liberation and some of the difficulties encountered in personal relationships. Featuring Mike Wallace of Sixty Minutes.

results.title: Faster pussycat kill, kill. Mondo topless
results.creator_credit: Eve Productions, Russ Meyer and Eve Meyer
results.brief_description: Russ Meyer made famous this b-grade exploitation style of popular culture and in his films explored the people living on the edge or outside of the mainstream culture of the day. “Faster Pussycat Kill! Kill!” a cult classic centres around three women who are on a wild rampage of violence and revenge, a new breed of violence where sex is it’s favourite mantle and terrorizing people the order of the day. These “homicidal go-go’s” start their journey with a drag race across the desert followed by a violent showdown with local ranchers. The film is filled with hard-line one-liners, for example in answering the question “What’s the point?” the ringleader vixen Varla (Tura Satana) replies “The point is of no return, and you’ve just crossed it”. The second film “Mondo Topless” equally a cult classic is a montage of kinky topless go-go dancers accompanied with voice overs from the dancers talking about thier trade, motivations and views of their sexuality, (more titillating than informative - no pun intended).

results.title: Fashions, flowers and favourites
results.creator_credit: Movietonenews, Tourist Development Authority of Victoria, Frank Killian and Syd Wood
results.brief_description: Shows numerous scenes in and around Melbourne (1962?) including activities such as the Melbourne Cup, sailing on Albert Park Lake, eating out and nightlife, the Miss Australia judging, the Sidney Myer Music Bowl and the Royal Botanic Gardens. Commentry by David Low and Bert Bryant.
